snippet.textDisplay:
The many worlds interpretation is highly flawed. First off the obvious criticism: it's not testable, so it's not useful.

Now the more nuanced criticism: why does the state split at all ? If it's all one wavefunction of the universe why is there a split at level of the individual quantum interaction? If the universe is all one wave function how can you say an individual part goes one way or the other at all? The individual interactions being describing where particles can go multiple paths at once are based on flawed descriptions of undescribable components of the wave function of the universe. Quantum field theory is incredibly accurate in it's predictions, but neither measurements nor theories are ever 100% accurate, there is always a degree of error. When you are measuring a specific property of the universal wave-function, you always measure a pre-defined property based on a purely creative hypothesis. This hypothesis can be measured with an everpresent degree of inaccuracy based on the properties the Creator and other theories pre- defined.

The many worlds interpretation is a failure to understand that our theories only represent the information we subjectively share with each other. When we can agree to six - sigma degrees of accuracy we say, there's a particle there. But really you just have information about the possible location of a probably inaccurate concept you made up to explain what matter is made of. So there are never any "quantum interactions" that "split the universe". All that the theory describes, is that there are an infinite number of ways to split the possible ways the universe could play out in our minds. We can imagine an infinite number of ways the individual components of matter could go, but there are no perfectly confirmable components. There is only the wavefunction of the universe, or probably not even a wave function (another inaccurate concept) only universe.

Quantum information theory is a lot more promising, along with Quantum Darwinism and Zen

snippet.textDisplay:
If we play out this idea even further. Once all the matter in the universe has broken down, when all the stars are burnt out, and when all the black holes radiate their collected energy out. All the energy locked up in matter in the universe is now, a wave. Potentially, with time, all these waves will eventually "synchronize" and the mess of waves of space time will be one uniform wave, that, just maybe, when its peak and trough reach a max/min point, it may BANG into the start of a new universe from the old. Potentially this would be analogous to "observing" the universe and collapsing the wave function. That is if the wave function is "uniform" or stable in a way, wouldnt that mean its properties would/could be known.



I like this thought because it means that universe feels more cyclical and alive. A universe that beats itself into an existence that is unique, finite but still potentially infinite in its endless cycles....wait wasnt this a futurama episode?



Edit: Yip. Season 6, Ep 7: The Late Philip J. Fry

snippet.textDisplay: Many Worlds is the most mathematically simple explanation. Occam's Razor applies.  The Universe just does its own thing. It doesn't care whether our puny little brains evolved to hunt on the savannah can make sense of it or not, it just is what it is. If we balk at the Many Worlds theory it's only because it makes us even less significant as individuals than we already were. Even though we're all good materialists these days we still like to think that we're unique individuals. But Many Worlds implies there are effectively infinite variations of me running around out there none of which matter any more or less than any other.

snippet.textDisplay: Ok...if this branching is true, then what is stopping me from CHOOSING the outcome of each particular incident or at least the ones that I want to affect by choosing which branch I will travel on. I ask this due to the theory of meditation, concentration or prayer CAN affect the outcome of our lives. In my view if I grab a nickel from a table with my right hand and I am holding it in my closed fist then I choose to concentrate/pray/meditate on the "ABSOLUTE BELIEF" that the nickel is TRULY not in my RIGHT hand but  IS and ALWAYS WAS in my LEFT hand, and I mean I Have to try to TRULY BELIEVE as much as I actually am able to.....well chances are its not gonna actually show up magically in my other hand without some slight of hand.  This goes for physically and mathematically, the outcome isnt gonna happen supposedly....BUT, math is the universal language....And for every single extra person that is added into this equation and trys to "BELIEVE" that the nickel was in the LEFT hand the whole time then the mathematical probability changes, at least on paper and numbers wise, and the chance it actually will be in the LEFT hand gets a very very small amount more realistic and factual. ANYWAY,  where is that science or math that touches on why that isnt possible...seems to me that if it is happening so often then it should easier for us to just decide, "Hey this lottery ticket will be the 10 million dollar one"....and something has to be blocking that from being a fact or we would be doing it.

snippet.textDisplay: Wait, what? Is it because the interference pattern on the target detector shows no quantum information about the photons?

snippet.textDisplay:
Ok so I don't agree that it's possible there is a version of every person in the world who is President of USA. All worlds would need to converge on the conception of a child, because you are only "you" because of that exact sperm that fertilized that exact egg. There is no other version of "you" that was conceived with a different sperm, because that
would not be "you". Thus, for there to be the possibility of every person in the world is President of USA, all of the many worlds would need to converge on the conception of each person in the world. It's not possible for your parents to have moved to USA and for you to be born there on a different day. All they have to do is have sex at a slightly different time and it changes everything. A different sperm fertilizes the egg and some other child is born who isn't you at all.
This would mean that the best case would be every American could have the possibility of being President, but everyone not born in America couldn't because their parents lives would change too drastically for you to even be born.
Does this make sense to anyone?

It's not possible for your parents to have moved to USA and for you to be born there on a different day. All they have to do is have sex at a slightly different time and it changes everything. A different sperm fertilizes the egg and some other child is born who isn't you at all.
This would mean that the best case would be every American could have the possibility of being President, but everyone not born in America couldn't because their parents lives would change too drastically for you to even be born.
Does this make sense to anyone?

snippet.textDisplay:
Disclaimer: In NO way at all do I claim to be anyone’s idea of a physicist. Heck, I took History and Economics in high skool !! Thus, I freely admit that I do not understand more than about a third of what was said in the explanations.

But I have a massive problem with this whole theory.

Here’s my thinking: Determining the state of the cat involves a decision with two possible options – opening the box or not opening the box, resulting, after all of the entanglement, in two parallel “worlds”.

Now extrapolate that split across every single decision made every second by every man, woman and child alive today.


But we ain’t even begun to scratch the surface yet !! Just for starters, we need to continue the aforementioned extrapolation to include every binary decision split across every second per day per month per year … for every person that has ever lived over the 40,000 (I’m being generous here) years of human existence.

Yet, apparently, for each of those decisions there are two parallel worlds !!

Naturally, I expect there will be plenty of more learned people than I who are already chaffing at the bit to tell me just how wrong I am.
So, scientists … Go for it !!




(Of course, I failed to include decisions made by non-human beings … after all, Schrodinger included his cat.
What about the first Homo Erectus that decided to shape his flint in a particular way, instead of another ?? Surely that decision is deserving of its’ own parallel world/universe and would have resulted in half of the "worlds" where humans did not survive to evolve.)

snippet.textDisplay:
Yes, there is no cat and apparatus in the box. There is a wave function. When the thinker observes the wave function it may (or may not) collapse into an empty box, apparatus and a cat. It collapses into an empty box, apparatus and a cat when the observer (the thinker doing thought experiments) choses the destiny of the wave function to become a box, apparatus and a cat. If the observer (the thinker doing the thought experiment) choses the destiny to be a man and a ball and the man kicks the ball, then the wave function collapses into a man kicking a ball.

I’m not convinced that determining a start point (a classical concept) of box, apparatus and cat, can be used to examine wave functions.

You use the phrase 'When no measurement has been made' ? A measurement (of a start point) was made by placing 'a cat' and 'apparatus' in 'a box'. 

‘Isolated’ ? But nothing is isolated, unless you assume it is isolated at the start point. There is no start point unless a measurement is made.

Multi-universes seems to me to be a way to create a new ‘start point’ to remove the need for the previously thought to be valid ‘start point’ and convince oneself ‘no start point’ (measurement) exists so this is now valid.

I prefer the following analogy. The universe and everything in it is blind. The blind man believes he can see.... and believes what he sees. Seeing is measurement and measurement is seeing.

The man who is blind and knows that he is blind and cannot see. He it is who is able to see what he needs to see.

snippet.textDisplay:
With Schrödinger’s cat, isn’t the detector measuring the state of the decay, therefore wouldn’t the detector itself cause the waveform to collapse into one outcome or the other, but until we become entangled in that outcome we cant see what it is, I think this is a better way to look at it rather than that all outcomes happen, we just seem (For some reason) to experience one of the most probable...

In addition, the absence of a deterministic outcome does not necessarily mean that many worlds exist, and although I do subscribe to this theory, I think we need to be careful of endorsing these theories with no real qualitative evidence.

In addition, the divergence of the different many worlds would suggest that the path of the branches usually choose the most likely deterministic option, as the outcomes of cause and effect usually concern the most likely outcomes, e.g if I was to drop a brick on my foot, it is possible that that brick could pass through my foot before it hits, but of course, no matter how many times we do this experiment the more likely outcome will occur, the brick hits my foot. So many worlds does not mean that every possible outcome exists, only that the most likely outcome exists, and therefore we are back to square one again, in that not everything is happening at once, only the most probable outcome is happening.

snippet.textDisplay:
I wish the Schrödinger's cat experiment could be deleted from our collective minds - every time it's brought up, my disagreement with the very concept makes me want to oppose everything else discussed. Let me just say before I go on: I dont disagree with the complex scientific concepts and the whole superposition etc ideas... Im not knowledgable enough about physics to take such a stance and the explanations of quantum physics on their own make some degree of sense to me, even if I struggle with linking what superpositions of electrons mean to the macro-world we live in.

Anyways, that's not the core of my problem. The cat example is counterproductive to me, because what is described in it is wrong. We're not talking about quantum states but large living or dead structures. Inside the box, either of 2 things happened: the cat died or the cat didnt die. The subjective observer that cant see inside the box doesnt know it yet. An observer with better tools might be able to - thermal cameras could reveal the state long before the box is opened and a multitude of other observation methods could be used. "Not knowing" shouldnt be equated with "both exist at the same time until we know". In other words, the tree in the forest falls whether you are there to observe it or not. When I roll a die under a cup, it can be in any of 6 (with a d6) states - but it already is in that state before I check myself.
Just adding the decaying atom to the mix doesnt, to me, change this. After all, everything around us has probabilities of outcome and unknowable causes on microscopic levels...
Bottom line: Im not disputing the validity of quantum mechanics, far from me, but Im disputing the usefulness of a thought experiment that was designed to ridicule the concept first and is just simply wrong when used to do the opposite.

snippet.textDisplay:
So if two electrons separated by lightyears are entangled and one changes and the other changes instantly, is it because they're connected by a wave?


So there's a very, very, very large number of universes, but seemingly finite?


Does any of this knowledge have any application if there's no involvement between these universes?


Isn't it theoretically possible there are no universes where he's president, however the odds of there being such a universe is very, very, very likely?


If energy is conserved by splitting it in half, then does that mean the second one more electron gets quantum entangled, that we instantly lose half the energy in our universe? How is this possible without us noticing? Will we eventually theoretically run out of energy in our universe, at an exponential speed?


How is radioactive decay not deterministic? I know it's the textbook example of "randomness", "unpredictability", and we don't have any way of knowing what it will be, however I feel (and I know science doesn't care about my feelings) that even this process, seemingly random and unpredictable, still obeys the laws of physics, and through exactly every event that's occurred before it, that atom will or won't decay due to the events prior and that is guaranteed to happen because of everything before it, ie. it's deterministic. Everything is destined.
snippet.textOriginal:
So if two electrons separated by lightyears are entangled and one changes and the other changes instantly, is it because they're connected by a wave?


So there's a very, very, very large number of universes, but seemingly finite?


Does any of this knowledge have any application if there's no involvement between these universes?


Isn't it theoretically possible there are no universes where he's president, however the odds of there being such a universe is very, very, very likely?


If energy is conserved by splitting it in half, then does that mean the second one more electron gets quantum entangled, that we instantly lose half the energy in our universe? How is this possible without us noticing? Will we eventually theoretically run out of energy in our universe, at an exponential speed?


How is radioactive decay not deterministic? I know it's the textbook example of "randomness", "unpredictability", and we don't have any way of knowing what it will be, however I *feel* (and I know science doesn't care about my feelings) that even this process, seemingly random and unpredictable, still obeys the laws of physics, and through exactly every event that's occurred before it, that atom will or won't decay *due to* the events prior and that is *guaranteed* to happen because of everything before it, ie. it's deterministic. Everything is destined.

snippet.textDisplay: I am still not convinced that the total energy remains the same. For example, let's take the universe at its inception, when the very first entaglement happened, and the universe branched out in to two parallel universes. These two universes must have almost exactly the same configuration and therefore the same total energy per universe. In other words if the pre branch universe had x amount of total energy, the both the post branch universes must have x amount of total energy each for the configurations to be the same. Therefore now the total energy is 2x. Where did the extra x amount come from?

snippet.textDisplay: 1. All probable paths exist, you're interacting in a restrictive manner of three dimensions while the space around you is of 4 or more dimensions so what you are observing isn't the full action/reaction picture , 2. The path you pick determines the outcome for you while the other observers around you are alternate probable perspectives that follow the same path with you of you're line of the path of least resistance for you at every given time. If it's probable it exist (today you didn't go to work but it was most probable that you would) this would mean that both states of probability exist but you took the path to the one that was least probable to see if you could change the outcome of your path. The action and reaction with space around us is what makes us experience "time". To better understand what time and how we interact with the state of space around us is to get a better understanding of the full picture and the ability to interact with that state of space in 4+ dimensions. One of the tools needed is to create a mapping system that i wont go into right now. Our perception of time is but the action/reaction with the state of space that's around us. When you change the way you interact with each state of energy/space the perception of time changes with it.

snippet.textDisplay: I swear I still don't understand this "when observed" thing about particle behavior. And I've watched so many things about the doube slit experiment. I mean, how could a simple observation affect results? In fact, how can you know what the results are when no one observes them, if no one observes them? And how could an eye, a receptor of photons, interact with those particles in any way? How the hell do you even reach that conclusion? That particles behave differently when you watch them. Surely it must be some sort of misunderstanding of particle behavior. Something we're missing. It sounds like something out of a Deepak Chopra book.

snippet.textDisplay: Kind of a weird thought. Quantum entanglement might explain love. Two separate wave forms (although we might not be a wave form, maybe our thoughts or consciousness is?) become one and become entangled. At which point, one consciousness is inextricably linked to another consciousness. To the extent that distance does not matter. Things that affect one effects the other instantaneously regardless of distance. These entangled particles become one single wave function and can be described as a single function. Basically, an entangled global consciousness. (If consciousness is a wave function)
